chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect acute kidney injury?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Suspect acute kidney injury (AKI) in anyone with:
    • Symptoms and signs such as:
      • Nausea and vomiting, or diarrhoea, evidence of dehydration.
      • Reduced urine output or changes to urine colour.
      • Confusion, fatigue, and drowsiness. 
    • An acute illness and any of the following:
      • Age of 65 years or over.
      • A history of acute kidney injury.
      • Chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate [eGFR] less than 60mL/min/1.73m2).
      • Symptoms or history of urological obstruction or conditions which may lead to obstruction.
      • Chronic conditions such as heart failure and liver disease and diabetes mellitus.
      • Neurological or cognitive impairment or disability (which may limit fluid intake because of reliance on a carer).
      • Sepsis.
      • Nephrotoxic drug use within the last week (especially if hypovolaemic) — for example, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor antagonists (ARBs), and diuretics.
      • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents within the past week.
      • Cancer and cancer therapy (risk will depend on the type of cancer, proposed treatment and premorbid risk factors). 
      • Immunocompromise (for example HIV infection).
      • Toxins (for example some herbal remedies, poisonous plants and animals).
    • An illness with no clear acute component and any of the following:
      • Chronic kidney disease (especially stage 3B, 4, or 5), or urological disease.
      • New onset or significant worsening of urological symptoms.
      • Symptoms or signs of a multi-system disease affecting the kidneys and other organ systems (for example signs or symptoms of acute kidney injury, plus a purpuric rash in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura).
      • Symptoms suggesting the presence of complications of acute kidney injury. 
    • An acute kidney injury warning stage test result generated from electronic detection systems in a biochemistry laboratory. This flags up changes in creatinine levels suggestive of AKI for the person receiving the result in primary care.
      • If alerted to a creatinine change suggesting a potential case of AKI, consider the patient and clinical picture, not solely the result of the test, in order to make a clinical diagnosis. It is important to consider why the blood test was taken (for example assessment of acute illness, chronic disease monitoring, or drug monitoring). For more information, see the sections on Responding to AKI warning stage test results and Diagnosis of AKI.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Considering acute kidney injury (AKI) as a possibility

  • If there are no symptoms or signs, AKI is often not recognised immediately. Early detection and intervention can improve outcomes as AKI is a potentially reversible process [Larmour and Maxwell, 2015]. 

Symptoms of acute kidney injury

  • CKS has listed symptoms and signs which may indicate acute kidney injury on the basis of expert consensus opinion in a best practice guideline for primary care from Think Kidneys [Think Kidneys, 2016a], the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline development group (GDG) for Acute kidney injury: prevention, detection and management [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles on the management of AKI [Thornburg and Gray-Vickrey, 2016; Levey and James, 2017].  
  • However, it is important to note that expert opinion in review articles and a textbook explains that AKI is often asymptomatic in its early stages, with symptoms and signs of fluid or waste product accumulation, or electrolyte imbalance rarely apparent until the condition is advanced. Even when symptoms and signs develop they are often very non-specific [Firth, 2010; Thornburg and Gray-Vickrey, 2016; Levey and James, 2017]. Expert reviewers of this CKS topic are of the opinion that the symptoms in acute kidney injury are usually related to the underlying cause(s), rather than the acute kidney injury itself.

Acute illness in people with risk factors

  • NICE recommends investigating people with acute illness who are considered to be at increased risk of acute kidney injury based on risk factors (which were extrapolated from tools developed in hospital populations and the clinical experience of the guideline development group). No published validated scores to predict acute kidney injury in primary care were identified. However, the NICE guideline development group consensus was that these risk factors were equally applicable to acutely unwell people in primary care [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013; Think Kidneys, 2015]. 
  • CKS has also added cancer and cancer therapy, immunocompromise, and toxins as risk factors that should increase suspicion of AKI in a person with acute illness in line with subsequent expert opinion from Think Kidneys [Think Kidneys, 2015; Think Kidneys, 2016a; Think Kidneys, 2017] and review articles [Larmour and Maxwell, 2015; Mesropian et al, 2016; Levey and James, 2017].

People with illness with no clear acute component (including symptoms suggestive of complications)

  • This recommendation is based on the NICE guideline Acute kidney injury: prevention, detection and management [NICE, 2013b]. The NICE GDG were of the opinion that early consideration of AKI with illness with no clear acute component may prevent a delay in treatment and improve outcomes and is unlikely to cause harm. The GDG thought that it was important to increase awareness of the potential for AKI in circumstances that may be more common in a primary care setting [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013].

Acute kidney injury warning stage test result

  • The information on AKI warning stage test results to help identify people with AKI at an earlier stage is based on expert consensus opinion in a best practice guideline for primary care [Think Kidneys, 2016a]. A British Journal of General Practice editorial also discussed the NHS England mandate for all UK NHS Trusts to implement into their laboratories the NHS AKI scoring algorithm [Tollitt et al, 2017]. Although evidence for use of e-alerts in primary care is lacking, implementation for inpatients has had positive results in terms of timely medication review and management interventions, and reduction in mortality [Emmett et al, 2017]. 
    • CKS has recommended these alerts are used to suspect rather than diagnose AKI because it is a clinical diagnosis and AKI alerts are not a substitute for inspection and comparison of the person's serum creatinine measurements [Think Kidneys, 2016a]. In addition, the reduced frequency of phlebotomy in primary compared with secondary care increases the risk of misclassification of results as the median of the last year's creatinine values may be used as a baseline in a large proportion of primary care patients for whom a previous result within 7 days is not available [Emmett et al, 2017; Tollitt et al, 2017].
